key_questions.Who are the distinct types of users?: Primary: Game Masters running sessions in Foundry VTT who need to control many minion tokens efficiently. Secondary: Players are impacted by smoother turn flow but are not direct operators.
key_questions.What are the key goals, behaviors, or de: GM wants to group minions into mobs and issue one command so all minions act together; choose and apply strategies such as attack most powerful/weakest, defend leader, attack most damaged; avoid per-token clicking.
key_questions.Who are the primary users or stakeholder: Game Masters are the primary users; players experience the outcomes (faster, consistent combat turns).
key_questions.What is the first thing users will try t: Select several minion tokens in Foundry VTT, create a mob from them, and apply a strategy so they act together on a target.
key_questions.What problems, inefficiencies, or workar: Eliminates clicking every individual minion to perform the same action and the resulting slow, inconsistent execution.
key_questions.Where are users currently struggling, ge: Managing many minions during combatâ€”selecting targets, issuing repeated actions, and keeping actions synchronized across minions.
key_questions.What other systems, data sources, or too: Needs to integrate with Foundry Virtual Tabletop (tokens/actors, targeting, movement/attack actions). No other external systems mentioned.
key_questions.What are the key behaviors or integratio: Create mobs from existing minion tokens/actors; hook into Foundry actions for selecting targets, executing attacks/moves; apply chosen strategy so all mob members follow it.
key_questions.What is the business domain we are model: Virtual tabletop combat management within Foundry VTT, focused on minion grouping and coordinated actions.
key_questions.What are the core business concepts and: Minion (individual token), Mob (collection of minions acting together), Strategy (rules for choosing targets/behavior), Target (actor chosen by strategy), Action (attack/defend/move) executed by mob members.
key_questions.What are the distinct sub-domains or bus: Grouping/minion-to-mob management; strategy selection/configuration; target selection; coordinated action execution; possibly mob template/spawn management.
key_questions.What are the boundaries between differen: Mob management (grouping, membership) is separate from strategy logic (how to pick targets/behaviors) and from Foundry core mechanics (movement/attack resolution). Limited detail on technical boundaries in the source.
key_questions.What domain events occur in this busines: Mob created, minions added/removed, strategy selected/changed, target chosen, mob action executed, mob disbanded.
key_questions.What are the key business rules and cons: Mobs act together under a selected strategy (e.g., attack most powerful/weakest, defend leader, attack most damaged); actions must operate within Foundry VTT mechanics. Additional rules (range, movement, templates) are not specified.
key_questions.What domain language do business experts: Terms: minion, mob, group, strategy (attack most powerful/weakest, defend leader, attack most damaged), spawn, template, choose targets, area attack, Foundry Virtual Tabletop.

input_description.summary: User provided project description for mob/minion grouping and strategy execution within Foundry VTT.
